title: How to Detect Gas Leaks
content: To detect an LPG gas leak: 1) Use your nose - LPG has an added smell (mercaptan) that smells like rotten eggs. 2) Listen for hissing sounds near the cylinder or connections. 3) Apply soapy water to connections - bubbles indicate a leak. 4) Never use a flame to check for leaks. If you detect a leak: turn off the cylinder valve immediately, open windows for ventilation, do not operate electrical switches, evacuate the area, and call EnergiChain support at 0700-123-456.

title: Safe LPG Cylinder Storage
content: Store LPG cylinders upright in a well-ventilated area away from heat sources. Keep cylinders at least 1.5 meters away from stoves, heaters, and direct sunlight. Never store cylinders in basements, enclosed spaces, or near flammable materials. Outdoor storage is preferred. Indoor storage must have adequate ventilation. Keep the area around cylinders clear of combustible materials. Temperature should not exceed 50Â°C.

title: Cylinder Connection Safety
content: Before connecting: 1) Check the regulator and hose for cracks or damage. 2) Ensure the cylinder valve is closed. 3) Remove the safety cap from the cylinder. 4) Connect the regulator hand-tight, do not use tools. 5) Check for leaks with soapy water. 6) Open the valve slowly. Replace hoses every 2 years or if damaged. Never use open flames to check connections.

title: Fire Safety with LPG
content: In case of LPG fire: 1) Evacuate everyone immediately. 2) Call fire services (999). 3) If safe, turn off the cylinder valve. 4) Do not attempt to extinguish large fires yourself. 5) Use a dry powder fire extinguisher for small fires. Never use water on LPG fires. Keep a fire extinguisher nearby. Have an emergency plan and practice it with family members.
